'Cushing's syndrome' describes the signs and symptoms associated with prolonged
exposure to inappropriately high levels of the hormone cortisol. This can be
caused by taking glucocorticoid drugs, or diseases that result in excess
cortisol, adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), or CRH levels. Kumar, Abbas,
Fausto. Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 7th ed. Elsevier-
Saunders; New York, 2005.

Cushing's disease refers to a pituitary-dependent cause of Cushing's syndrome: a
tumor (adenoma) in the pituitary gland produces large amounts of ACTH, causing
the adrenal glands to produce elevated levels of cortisol. It is the most common
non-iatrogenic cause of Cushing's syndrome, responsible for 70% of cases
excluding glucocorticoid related cases. Schwartz's principles of surgery,
8th ed., p.1455. [http://endocrine.niddk.nih.g-
ov/pubs/cushings/cushings.htm#1 Cushingâs Syndrome] at The National Endocrine
and Metabolic Diseases Information Service. July 2008. Citing: Nieman LK, Ilias
I. "Evaluation and treatment of Cushingâs syndrome". The Journal of American
Medicine 2005; 118(12), 1340â1346.

This pathology was described by Harvey Cushing in 1932. The syndrome is also called 'Itsenko-Cushing syndrome', 'hyperadrenocorticism' or
'hypercorticism'.

Cushing's syndrome is not confined to humans and is also a relatively common
condition in domestic dogs and horses. It also occurs in cats, but rarely.

It should not be confused with Cushing's triad, a disease state resulting from
increased intracranial pressure.
